General course objectives:
General course objectives
A general introduction, particularly to chemical and biochemical systems and phenomena with properties closely associated with their (few) nanometer sizes. Introduction of theoretical concepts and experimental techniques in nanoscale chemistry and biochemistry. Insight in relation to nanoscale chemistry, energy and biotechnology.
Learning objectives:
A student who has met the objectives of the course will be able to:
Be able to understand physical-chemical laws for chemistry and biotechnology in the nanometer range.
Know experimental techniques for describing chemical and biotechnological nanoscale phenomena.
Become familiar with important examples of nanoscale chemical and biological phenomena and systems (nanotubes, quantum dots, etc.).
Understand the working principles of central nanotechnological methods such as scanning tunneling and atomic force microscopy (STM and AFM), electrochemistry, and optical spectroscopy.
Be able to synthesize and handle nanoscale chemical systems of a controlled size such as metallic nanoparticles.
Understand the ultrafast optical and electric response of nanomaterials, minimized spatial dimension versus time dimension.
Apply nanoscale materials in AFM and electrochemistry.
Understand the working principles of nanoscale components applied in energy and catalyst solutions such as solar cells and photocatalysts.
Content:
A chemistry course, linked to Nano*DTU with a focus on chemistry and biochemistry at the nanoscale.

Theoretical basis: Physical and chemical laws at the nanometer scale; inorganic and biological nanosystems; monolayers, semiconductor quantum dots, carbon nanotubes, metallic nanoparticles, and molecular machines as "working" chemical nanosystems.

The new tools: Mechanical forces and electrical currents at the nanoscale and single-molecule levels - the atomic force and scanning tunneling microscopes (AFM and STM); probe chemical kinetics at transient time scales with ultrafast spectroscopy; cutting-edge nanostructured solar cell devices; photocatalytic nanomaterials and fundamentals of their application; physics and chemistry of proteins, DNA and other biological nanostructures.

Experimental course part: Participation in the use of AFM and nanoparticle tracking analysis; Visualization of nano-objects by different nanoscale microscopies; chemical synthesis and characterization of metallic nanoparticles; fabricate nanomaterials-based prototype solar cells, and analyze experimental data; Implement photocatalytic dye reduction using nanoparticles.
Remarks:
Chemistry at the Nanoscale is integrated in DTU's nanotechnology initiative, NanoDTU.

Course material: Compendium, "Chemistry at the Nanoscale", Lab exercise manuals and original articles
